conclusion: Analyzing how shadows A, B, C, and D change when the light source moves forward above the objects, considering both location and size changes.
Object left: A cream/beige textured object (possibly bread/dough) with shadow A.
Object center-left: A black device (appears to be a camera or calculator) with shadow B.
Object center-right: A small gray/silver object (looks like a piece of metal or stone) with shadow C.
Object right: A peach/apricot with shadow D.
When a light source moves forward (closer to being directly above the objects), shadows change in location and size.
When the light source is more distant, shadows are cast farther from their objects.
When the light source moves forward/overhead, shadows move closer to the objects (directly beneath them).
In the second image, all shadows are now positioned closer to their respective objects.
When the light source is more distant, shadows appear larger/longer.
When the light source moves more directly overhead, shadows become smaller.
In the second image, all shadows have become noticeably smaller.
Shadow A (bread/dough object) becomes smaller and moves closer to the object.
Shadow B (camera/calculator) becomes smaller and moves closer to the object.
Shadow C (metal/stone piece) becomes smaller and moves closer to the object.
Shadow D (peach/apricot) becomes smaller and moves closer to the object.
In the first image, the shadows are larger and positioned farther away from their objects.
In the second image, the shadows are smaller and positioned closer to directly beneath their objects.

When the light source moves forward (to a more overhead position), shadows A, B, C, and D all decrease in size (become smaller/shorter) and move closer to their respective objects (shifting toward being directly beneath them).
This follows the principles of shadow formation, where more overhead lighting creates smaller shadows that fall closer to the objects casting them.
